newsitem.title: HONG KONG: "Highland Furies" last British regiment in HK.
newsitem.headline: "Highland Furies" last British regiment in HK.

text.p: The Scottish regiment chosen to represent the departing British at the ceremonies marking the handover of Hong Kong arrived in the British colony on Thursday for a historic 138-day tour of duty.

The pipes and drums of the Black Watch, nicknamed the "Highland Furies" by the French, will sound the end of more than 150 years of British colonial rule on June 30, 1997 when Hong Kong reverts to China.
Their tour won't be all spit and polish and ceremonial parades.
They will also assist the Hong Kong police with anti-smuggling patrols, conduct border observation duties and help guard key installations.
"However their most high profile role will be as ceremonial troops during the handover ceremonies in June," a garrison spokesman said in a statement.
Many of the 511 soldiers of the Black Watch, whose Latin motto means "Nobody provokes me without being hurt", are no strangers to Hong Kong.
The Black Watch was the resident infantry battalion of the Hong Kong Garrison from January 1993 until August 1994.
The Black Watch was formed in 1725 as a result of the Scottish Jacobite Rebellion of 1715 to oversee the warring Highland clans.
The force wore a tartan so dark it was almost black and as their role was to "watch" over the Highlands, it was dubbed "Am Freiceadan Dubh" in Gaelic which translates as the "Black Watch".
The French gave them another nickname after the Battle of Fontenoy in 1745 -- the Highland Furies.
Since the end of World War Two the regiment has served in Korea, Kenya and Cyprus and has conducted 11 tours of Northern Ireland.
British naval, airforce and specialists from other regiments will also be assigned to Hong Kong until the handover.
